questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Tyrosine is the amino acid forming Serotonin

options.label: B
options.text: Niacin deficiency is seen in Carcinoid syndrome

options.label: C
options.text: Tryptophan hydroxylase is required for Niacin synthesis

options.label: D
options.text: Decarboxylation of 5 hydroxy tryptophan forms niacin.

questions.correct_answer: B. Niacin deficiency is seen in Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: Match the following urinary odours with their corresponding diagnoses: Urinary Odour Diagnosis 1. Mousy odour a. DKA (Diabetic Ketoacidosis) 2. Fruity odour b. Hawkinsinuria 3. Cabbage odour c. Methionine malabsorption 4. Swimming pool odour d. PKU (Phenylketonuria) 5. Oast house odour e. Type 1 Tyrosinemia

A 45-year-old patient presents with episodes of palpitations, sweating, and severe headaches. These episodes occur intermittently and are associated with hypertension. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of plasma free metanephrines and urinary Vanillyl Mandelic Acid. Which of the following enzymes are directly involved in the synthesis of these metabolites?
Which of the following statements about Segawa syndrome is incorrect?

options.label: B
options.text: Patients have a defect in the GTP cyclohydrolase enzyme.

options.label: D
options.text: Females are more commonly affected than males.

questions.correct_answer: C. CSF Biopterin levels are elevated.
questions.explanation:
Segawa Syndrome / Dopa-responsive dystonia (DRD)

Inheritance Pattern

Autosomal dominant (Option A)

Clinical Features

Dystonia with diurnal variation (worsens in the afternoon and evening)

Incidence based on sex

More common in females than males (Option D)

Genetic Mutation

Defect in the GTP cyclohydrolase enzyme (Option B)

Biochemical Findings
  • Reduced tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) levels
  • Normal or high blood phenylalanine levels
  • CSF Biopterin levels are low

Diagnosis
  • Clinical observation of dystonia patterns
  • Genetic testing for GTP cyclohydrolase enzyme mutation

questions.text: A newborn screening test reveals elevated phenylalanine levels, prompting further investigation. Genetic testing indicates a defect in dihydrobiopterin reductase. Based on this information, Which type of phenylketonuria does the patient most likely have?
questions.explanation:
Type

Enzyme Defect

Description

Classic PKU (Option A)

Phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH)

Defect in PAH leads to elevated phenylalanine levels and symptoms such as developmental delays and musty odor.

Non-classical PKU Type II & III

Dihydrobiopterin reductase

Defect in dihydrobiopterin reductase, leading to elevated phenylalanine levels.

Non-classical PKU Type IV & V (Option C & D)

Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) formation

Defect in the formation of tetrahydrobiopterin, a cofactor needed for phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to hyperphenylalaninemia.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the ophthalmologist by his parents due to progressive vision loss, particularly at night. Fundoscopic examination reveals circular areas of chorioretinal atrophy and peripheral retinal degeneration. Laboratory tests indicate markedly elevated plasma ornithine levels. What is the primary biochemical defect in this patient's condition?

A 5-year-old boy is brought to recurrent kidney stones and abdominal pain. Urinalysis reveals hexagonal crystals, and a 24-hour urine test shows elevated levels of cystine. Which condition is the most likely diagnosis?

A 10-year-old girl is evaluated for developmental delay. Physical examination reveals a tall, thin build, scoliosis, and ectopia lentis. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of homocysteine and methionine in the plasma. Treatment is initiated with vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) and folate. Homocysteine levels improve, but methionine levels remain elevated. Based on this scenario, what type of defect does the patient most likely have?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Type - I Homocystinuria

Type - II Homocystinuria

Enzyme Deficiency

Cystathionine beta-synthase

Methionine synthase

Metabolic Pathway Affected

Homocysteine to cystathionine

Homocysteine to methionine

Elevated Metabolites

Homocysteine and methionine

Homocysteine and elevated levels of methionine

Biochemical Diagnosis
  • Low levels of cysteine.
  • High levels of methionine.
  • High levels of cysteine.
  • Low levels of methionine.

Treatment
  • Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) supplementation; low-methionine diet; cysteine supplementation

Vitamin B12 and folate supplementation; low-methionine diet

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought with recurrent episodes of a red, scaly rash that worsens with sun exposure, as well as intermittent episodes of diarrhea and mood changes. A urine sample reveals an abnormal presence of neutral amino acids. The patient's diet is balanced, and there is no history of similar symptoms in the family. Laboratory tests indicate a deficiency in niacin despite adequate dietary intake. What is the underlying cause of the patient's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Deficiency in the neutral amino acid transporter

questions.correct_answer: B. Deficiency in the neutral amino acid transporter

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with symptoms of diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. On further investigation, his diet is found to be predominantly corn-based, and he has a history of alcohol use disorder. Laboratory tests reveal low levels of tryptophan and niacin in his blood. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely contributing to the patient's condition?
Which of the following statements about the metabolism of phenylalanine is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Phenylalanine is converted to tyrosine catalyzed by phenylalanine hydroxylase.

options.label: B
options.text: Phenylalanine on transamination gets converted to phenylpyruvate

options.label: C
options.text: Phenylpyruvate on oxidation yields phenyl lactate

options.label: D
options.text: Phenylpyruvate on oxidative decarboxylation forms phenylacetate.

questions.correct_answer: C. Phenylpyruvate on oxidation yields phenyl lactate
questions.explanation:
Major Fate
  • Phenylalanine is converted into tyrosine by the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase.
  • Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase results in Phenylketonuria.
  • It requires tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) as a cofactor

Minor Fate

Phenylalanine is converted into phenylpyruvate by transamination.

Phenylpyruvate can further undergo different pathways:

  • Phenylpyruvate can be reduced to phenyl lactate
  • Phenylpyruvate undergoes oxidative decarboxylation, forming phenylacetate
  • Phenylacetate combines with glutamine to form phenylacetylglutamine, which is excreted in the urine.

questions.text: Which of the following TCA intermediates is not formed by glucogenic amino acids?
Which of the following amino acids are both glucogenic and ketogenic?
questions.explanation:
Purely Ketogenic

Purely Glucogenic

Both Ketogenic and Glucogenic

On catabolism gives only acetyl CoA

On catabolism gives only pyruvate

Substance on catabolism gives one of the glycolytic intermediate -Pyruvate or TCA cycle intermediate

other than Acetyl CoA

Amino acids are:

  • Leucine
  • Lysine

Amino acids are:

  • Alanine: On transamination yields pyruvate.
  • Glycine: Simplest amino acid.
  • 3-hydroxyl group- containing amino acids
    • Serine
    • Threonine
    • Hydroxyproline
  • Sulphur-containing amino acid
    • Cysteine

Amino acids are:

  • Aromatic amino acids
    • Phenylalanine
    • Tyrosine
    • Tryptophan
  • Branched-chain amino acid
    • Isoleucine
    • Threonine

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant has been having developmental delays. Further examination reveals a defect in the enzyme called phenylalanine hydroxylase. Which of the following urine odor is seen in this infant?
questions.explanation:
ODOUR

DISORDERS

Musty/ Mousy odour

PKU

Fruity odour

DKA (diabetic ketoacidosis)

Cabbage odour

Type 1 Tyrosinemia

Burnt sugar

Maple syrup urine disease

Oast house or beer baby syndrome

Hypermethioninemia

Swimming pool odour

Hawkinsinuria

Tom-cat urine odour

Multiple carboxylase deficiency

Sweaty feet odour

Isovaleric acidemia

Fish odour

Trimethylaminuria

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with a lack of pigmentation in their skin, hair, and eyes. The parents are concerned about the child's sensitivity to sunlight and the involuntary back-and-forth eye movements that the child exhibits. A significant decrease in melanin pigmentation is present. Which of the following enzymes is absent or deficient in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Reaction

Enzyme

Tyrosine to DOPA

Tyrosine hydroxylase/ Tyrosinase

DOPA to Melanin

Non-enzyme catalyzed chemical reaction

questions.text: Tyrosine is involved in the synthesis of multiple neurotransmitters. Match the following neurotransmitters with the corresponding enzymes involved in their synthesis? Neurotransmitter Enzyme 1. Dihydroxy phenylalanine (DOPA) a. Dopamine beta-hydroxylase 2. Dopamine b. N-methyl transferase 3. Norepinephrine c. Tyrosine hydroxylase 4. Epinephrine d. DOPA Decarboxylase
questions.explanation:
Reaction

Enzyme

Tyrosine to dihydroxy phenylalanine (DOPA)

Tyrosine hydroxylase

DOPA to Dopamine

DOPA Decarboxylase (uses PLP as a coenzyme)

Dopamine to Norepinephrine

Dopamine beta-hydroxylase (depends on

Vitamin C)

Norepinephrine to epinephrine

N-methyl transferase (S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) is the methyl donor)

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to poor weight gain, vomiting, and yellowing of the skin and eyes. Genetic testing confirms a deficiency in fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase. The physician recommends a low-protein diet and the drug Nitisinone. Which of the following is not an indication of Nitisinone?
questions.explanation:
Tyrosinemia type I

Nitisinone inhibits the enzyme Parahydroxy phenylpyruvate dioxygenase, preventing the tyrosine metabolism upstream and reducing the accumulation of toxic maleylacetoacetate and fumarylacetoacetate.

Alkaptonuria

Nitisinone is used in the treatment of Alkaptonuria by inhibiting the formation of Homogentisic acid.

Hawkinsinuria

Nitisinone is used to treat Hawkinsinuria, which is caused by a mutation in 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant presents with jaundice, hepatomegaly, and failure to thrive. The parents also report that the infant has episodes of vomiting and lethargy. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of tyrosine and succinylacetone in the blood and urine, along with signs of coagulopathy and renal tubular dysfunction. What is the most likely underlying metabolic disorder?
questions.explanation:
Disorder

Deficient Enzyme

Key Clinical Features

Tyrosinemia type I

Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase
  • Jaundice, hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, HCC, liver cirrhosis
  • Often presents with Fanconi syndrome and renal failure
  • Elevated tyrosine and succinylacetone (pathognomonic)

Tyrosinemia type II

Tyrosine aminotransferase
  • Painful corneal erosions, palmoplantar hyperkeratosis
  • Also known as oculocutaneous tyrosinemia
  • Elevated tyrosine

Tyrosinemia type III

p-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase
  • Recurrent seizures, intermittent ataxia
  • Elevated tyrosine and 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate

Alkaptonuria (Black urine disease)

Homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase
  • Dark urine, ochronosis, arthritis
  • Black or brown pigmentation of sclera (Ochronosis) and ear cartilage
  • Elevated homogentisic acid

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the clinic by his parents due to darkening of urine upon standing and brownish discolouration of the sclera and ear cartilage. The parents also report that their child has been experiencing joint pain. Upon further investigation, the physician suspects a tyrosine metabolic disorder and orders urine tests. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.explanation:
1. Homogentisic Aciduria

Presence of homogentisic acid in the urine, which turns dark upon standing or when exposed to air.

2. Ochronosis

 Deposition of dark pigment in connective tissues, particularly in the ear cartilage, sclera, and other connective tissues, leading to bluish-black discolouration.

3. Arthropathy

Degenerative joint disease, especially affecting the spine and large joints, leading to chronic pain and stiffness.

4. Cardiac Involvement

Includes heart valve calcification and atherosclerosis due to the deposition of pigment in cardiac tissues.

Reaction

Enzyme

Associated Disorder

Tyrosine → p-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate

Tyrosine transaminase

Tyrosinemia type II

p-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate → Homogentisate

p-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase

Tyrosinemia type III

Homogentisate → Maleylacetoacetate

Homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase

Alkaptonuria

Maleylacetoacetate → Fumarylacetoacetate

Maleylacetoacetate isomerase

-

Fumarylacetoacetate → Fumarate + Acetoacetate

Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase

Tyrosinemia type I
